revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{About||The Meadow, a stadium in [[Chesham]]|Chesham United F.C.}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Meadow Lane | image = [[File:ViewFromKop.jpg|300px]] | fullname = Meadow Lane Stadium | nickname = | location = [[Nottingham]], [[England]] | coordinates = {{coord|52|56|33|N|1|8|14|W|display=inline,title}} | built = 1910 | opened = 1910 | surface = Grass | seating_capacity = 19,841 Safety Certificate [http://committee.nottinghamcity.gov.uk/documents/s58996/2017%2006%2023%20NCFC%20report%202017%20final.pdf] | tenants = [[Notts County F.C.]] (1910–present)
[[Notts County Ladies F.C.]] (2014–2017)
[[Nottingham R.F.C.]] (2006–2014) | dimensions = 114 x 76 yards (104 x 69 metres) }} The '''Meadow Lane Stadium''' (usually known simply as '''Meadow Lane'''){{Cite web |url=http://world.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/HistoryDetail/0,,10426~2105675,00.html |title=Notts County | Club | Meadow Lane | Meadow Lane — The Home Of Notts County FC |publisher=Nottscountyfc.premiumtv.co.uk |access-date=28 July 2009}} is a [[football (soccer)|football]] stadium in [[Nottingham]], [[England]]. It is the home ground of [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], who have played there since 1910. The stadium was also home to [[Notts County Ladies F.C.]] from 2014 until 2017. It currently has an all-seated capacity of 19,841 for Football League games. The record attendance is 47,310, who watched Notts lose 1–0 to [[York City]] in the [[FA Cup]] Sixth Round on 12 March 1955."Club Records". Notts County official website. Retrieved 2014-04-21 Meadow Lane lies just {{convert|300|yd|m|abbr=off|spell=in}} away from the [[City Ground]], home of [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. The two grounds are the closest in [[England]] and the second-closest in the [[United Kingdom]] after the grounds of [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] and [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]]. The Trent End of the City Ground is visible from parts of the [[Jimmy Sirrel]] stand and the [[Spion Kop (stadiums)|Spion Kop]]. The stadium also hosts the men's and women's football in the [[Varsity Series (Nottingham universities)|Varsity Series]] – a sporting series contested by [[Nottingham Trent University]] and the [[University of Nottingham]]. == History == Prior to 1910, Notts County played their home games across the [[River Trent]] at [[Trent Bridge]] as a tenant of [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club]]. [[Cricket]] took priority on the ground and the football club were often forced to play early and late season fixtures at other venues to avoid a clash.The Official History Notts County Tony Brown {{ISBN|1-874427-61-5}} [[The Football League]] eventually deemed that this practice was inappropriate and demanded that Notts either seek more favourable terms for the use of Trent Bridge or relocate to a new ground on which they could fulfil all of their fixtures. In 1910, a plot of land near the cattle market on the opposite side of the River Trent was leased from the city council and a new stadium hastily erected. Part of the new stadium was a temporary stand from Trent Bridge which was literally floated across the river. On 3 September 1910, County moved to Meadow Lane, the first game was a 1–1 draw with old rivals Nottingham Forest, played in front of {{formatnum:27000}} fans paying receipts of £775.The Magpies Keith Warsop page 52 {{ISBN|0-86023-214-X}} In 1920 the landlord, Nottingham Corporation, which leased the land to the club, came very close to removing the club from its premises to make way for an abattoir.[http://www.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10426~2155601,00.html nearly an abattoir] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924072522/http://www.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10426~2155601,00.html |date=24 September 2010 }} The stadium remained largely the same until 1923 when the [[Sneinton]] Side was replaced with a new stand, named the County Road Stand after the newly constructed road behind it. Meadow Lane was bombed during [[World War II]] forcing the club to suspend all fixtures during the 1942 season. The northern side of the Main Stand was badly damaged and the pitch left in an unplayable condition.[http://www.nottscounty-mad.co.uk/news/loadsngl.asp?cid=ED21 Meadow Lane bombed] [[File:MeadowLane2.jpg|thumb|The Jimmy Sirrel Stand]] [[File:MeadowLane3.jpg|thumb|The Derek Pavis Stand]] [[File:MeadowLane1.jpg|thumb|The Spion Kop]] [[File:Jimmy_and_Jack_statue.jpeg|thumb|right| Jimmy Sirrel & Jack Wheeler statue at Meadow Lane]] [[File:Nottingham.jpg|thumb|right|Aerial image showing the proximity of Meadow Lane (top) to the [[City Ground]]]] The stadium has played host to Forest games on a number of occasions. After the war, when flooding from the River Trent left the City Ground in an unplayable condition and again in 1968 when the Main Stand at the City Ground was destroyed by fire in a game against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]]. ==A new stadium== During the 1970s and 80s the stadium became increasingly dilapidated. The Meadow Lane End was demolished in 1978{{cite book|last=Wain|first=Paul|title=Notts County: a pictorial history|date=2004|publisher=Yore Publications|location=Harefield, U.K.|isbn=0-9547830-3-4|page=70}} and replaced by a building which housed new dressing rooms, a social club and a variety of other facilities designed to generate more income. There was no stand at this end for several years and Meadow Lane was reduced to a three sided ground. Eventually a small terrace was installed on this side. The [[Bradford City stadium fire]] and [[Hillsborough disaster]] brought the safety of football stadia into the public gaze and eventually the [[Taylor Report]] required that football clubs modernise their grounds. Meadow Lane was subsequently redeveloped during the early 1990s, although the work was planned before the report was issued. The Meadow Lane End, County Road Stand and Spion Kop were all demolished in the 1992 close season and replaced with the ''Family Stand'', the ''[[Jimmy Sirrel]] Stand'' and the ''Spion Kop Stand'' respectively. The Main Stand was replaced during the close season of 1994 by the ''Derek Pavis Stand''. In June 2002, as part of a sponsorship deal, the ground was briefly renamed the "Aaron Scargill Stadium". However, the ground reverted to its original name when the deal later fell through.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2179121.stm |title=UK | England | Magpies sponsor deal collapses |publisher=BBC News |date=7 August 2002 |accessdate=28 July 2009}} ==Meadow Lane today== The Derek Pavis Stand contains a number of conference and function facilities to complement ''The Broken Wheelbarrow'' bar behind the Family Stand. These host numerous functions throughout the year, ranging from social evenings organised by Notts County's supporter organisations, to wedding receptions and meetings of [[Protestantism|evangelical]] Christian churches.{{cite web|url=http://www.gracechurchnottingham.org |title=Grace Church Nottingham |publisher=Grace Church Nottingham |date= |accessdate=28 July 2009}} Away supporters are normally restricted to the Jimmy Sirrel stand, at the County Road side. This features a triangular gable (a replica of that on the old County Road stand) with the name of the club and its year of formation. Such gables are also present in the stadia of [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], and [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]. The Family Stand was renamed The Haydn Green Family Stand in 2007, after the man who saved Notts County from liquidation in 2003, by buying the lease on the ground and investing several million pounds. Haydn Green died suddenly in 2007 leaving an estate which still controls the lease on the ground. Outside the stadium on Meadow Lane is a bronze statue of [[Jimmy Sirrel]] and coach [[Jack Wheeler (footballer, born 1919)|Jack Wheeler]]. Entitled "Legends of the Lane", the statue was sculpted by Andy Edwards and unveiled on 5 May 2016. ==Rugby Union== In 2006, it was announced that [[Nottingham R.F.C.|Nottingham Rugby]] would play a number of home games at the stadium. It was further announced in May 2006 that Notts County and Nottingham Rugby were negotiating making the agreement permanent. In October 2006 it was announced that an agreement had been reached with Notts County, allowing Nottingham Rugby to play the remainder of their 2006/07 home fixtures at Meadow Lane. In 2014 it was announced that the rugby club would move out of Meadow Lane to play at The Bay, West Bridgford. ==Stands== For the 2017-18 season, the capacity set by the local authority for football is 19,841.[http://committee.nottinghamcity.gov.uk/documents/s58996/2017%2006%2023%20NCFC%20report%202017%20final.pdf] The stadium has a total of 20,211 seats. {| class="wikitable" cellpadding="3" style="text-align: left;" |- !Stand !Previously !Fans !Section Capacity !Stand Capacity |- |Derek Pavis Stand |Main Stand |Home |6,330 (Seats) 385 (VIPs/Press) |6,715 |- |Haydn Green Family Stand |Meadow Lane End |Home |2,137 (Seats) 144 (Boxes) |2,281 |- |Jimmy Sirrel Stand |County Road Stand |Home/Away or Away only |2,040 (Home) 3365 (Away) |5,775 (Away only) |- |Kop |Iremonger Road End |Home |2,024 (Upper Tier) 3,416 (Lower Tier) |5,440 |- |Total | | | |20,211 seats are available 19,841 (Football) |} == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == {{refbegin}} * The Magpies, Keith Warsop {{ISBN|978-0-86023-214-8}} {{refend}} ==External links== *[http://www.footballgroundguide.com/leagues/england/league-two/meadow-lane-notts-county.html Football Ground Guide Article] *[http://www.stadiumguide.com/meadowlane/ Stadium Guide Article] {{Notts County F.C.}} {{Football League Two venues}} [[Category:Sports venues in Nottingham]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Notts County F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1910]] [[Category:English Football League venues]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = A. J. Palumbo Center | nickname = | image = PalumboCenter1.jpg | image_size = 250px | location = 600 Forbes Avenue
Pittsburgh, PA 15282 | broke_ground = September 3, 1986 | opened = June 11, 1988{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lstRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3m0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5122,3095050|title=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|website=news.google.com}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = Duquesne University | operator = Duquesne University | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost= $10.1 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|10100000|1988}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = DRS Architects | former_names = | tenants = [[Duquesne Dukes]] ([[NCAA]]) (1988–present)
[[Pittsburgh Piranhas]] ([[Continental Basketball Association|CBA]]) (1994–1995) | seating_capacity = 4,390 }} '''A. J. Palumbo Center''' is a 4,406-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in the [[Bluff (Pittsburgh)|Uptown]] area of [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] served by exits on both [[Interstate 376]] and [[Interstate 579]]. The arena opened in 1988, and is part of [[Duquesne University]]. It is home to the Duquesne Dukes [[Duquesne Dukes men's basketball|basketball]], [[volleyball]] and [[collegiate wrestling|wrestling]] programs. The center hosts concerts, boxing, and other special events, and is capable of converting the seating arrangement into a sport, stage, or theatre setup.{{cite web |url=http://www.ajpalumbo.duq.edu/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225111812/http://www.ajpalumbo.duq.edu/ |archivedate=2008-02-25 |df= }} The facility was named in honor of its benefactor, Antonio J. Palumbo, who was elected to the Duquesne University board of directors and, in 1987, received an honorary doctorate of Business and Administration from Duquesne. Performance Magazine, a concert trade magazine, has consistently ranked the Palumbo Center as one of the top 10 grossing arenas of its size since its opening in 1988.{{cite web|url=http://pittsburgh.citysearch.com/profile/11278514/pittsburgh_pa/a_j_palumbo_center.html|title=A J Palumbo Center Pittsburgh|author=|date=|website=Citysearch|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618214425/http://pittsburgh.citysearch.com/profile/11278514/pittsburgh_pa/a_j_palumbo_center.html|archivedate=2007-06-18|df=}} ==Facilities== In 2006, the Palumbo Center underwent major renovations. In addition to resurfacing the basketball court, upgrading video monitors, and replacing some seating sections, the facility was updated and renovated to include: *New men's and women's basketball staff offices *Recruiting suite *Video breakdown room *Strength and conditioning facilities *Athletic trainer facilities The center houses the administrative offices for the athletic department and facility management. The center is also open to intramural sports and other recreation groups; however, in 2007, Duquesne University completed a new five-story recreational facility on Forbes Ave. near the A.J. Pablumbo Center, which has now become the primary facility for recreational sports and activities. After the 2009-2010 basketball season, Duquesne University began major renovations on the Palumbo Center. A new center-hung scoreboard was installed as well as new corner scoreboards. In addition, current bleacher seating on the north end of the arena was replaced with permanent stadium chairs. The University also received $1.8 million in private donations to upgrade the locker rooms for the men's and women's basketball teams and the volleyball team. It will be called the James and Janice Schaming Athletic Center, named after the largest donor.{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10356/1112497-135.stm|title=Duquesne: Another gift will add to Palumbo renovation|author=|date=|website=www.post-gazette.com}} ==Sports== Prior to the building of the facility, the men's basketball team played games at various sites around the city, including [[Mellon Arena|Pittsburgh Civic Arena]] (their exclusive home from 1964 to 1988, and used for occasional big games until 2009), [[Fitzgerald Field House]], and [[Duquesne Gardens]], as well as several high school gymnasiums. The first men's basketball game was played in the arena on December 3, 1988, in which Duquesne defeated St. Joseph's 73-69. As of January 2008, Duquesne men's basketball had 132-125 (.514) all-time record at the Palumbo Center.{{cite web|url=http://gwsports.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/012508aab.html|title=Men's Basketball To Face Duquesne Saturday Night in Pittsburgh|author=|date=|website=cstv.com}} The facility is used for most major sports at Duquesne, and has played host to [[National Invitation Tournament|NIT]] games, [[Women's National Invitation Tournament|WNIT]] games, high school post season championships, national wrestling championships, and [[Atlantic 10]] tournament competitions. During the 1994-95 basketball season, the Palumbo Center was the home of the Continental Basketball Association's Pittsburgh Piranhas. In the team's lone season in Pittsburgh, the Piranhas lost to the Yakima Sun Kings in the 1995 CBA finals. The new [[CONSOL Energy Center]] is now the home to the annual [[Pitt Panthers]]-Duquesne Dukes [[City Game]]{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sites.post-gazette.com/index.php/sports/dukes-blog/6888-qaa-submissions-120209-future-site-of-the-city-game-|title=Q&A submissions 12/02/09 -- Future site of the City Game?|first=Colin|last=Dunlap|date=|website=post-gazette.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20110609112355/http://blogs.sites.post-gazette.com/index.php/sports/dukes-blog/6888-qaa-submissions-120209-future-site-of-the-city-game-|archivedate=2011-06-09|df=}} as well as basketball games of regional interest, such as a men's game played on December 12, 2010 between the [[West Virginia Mountaineers]] and Duquesne.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sites.post-gazette.com/index.php/sports/dukes-blog?start=5|title=Sports|author=|date=|website=post-gazette.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20110117190134/http://blogs.sites.post-gazette.com/index.php/sports/dukes-blog?start=5|archivedate=2011-01-17|df=}} The Palumbo Center is also home to the women's volleyball team and hosted the Atlantic 10 Championship in 2012, won by Temple. For their 2017-18 season and part of the 2018-19 season, the arena will serve as the home of the [[2017–18 Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball team|Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball team]] for four games while the new UPMC Events Center is constructed on campus. [[File:PalumboCenter2.jpg|thumbnail|250px|Interior 2008]] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of
[[Duquesne Dukes]] Basketball | years = 1988- | before = [[Mellon Arena]] | after = future }} {{end}} ==See also== {{portal|Pittsburgh}} * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Palumbo Center}} *[http://www.duq.edu/palumbo-center/ Official Website] *[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10356/1112497-135.stm Duquesne: Another gift will add to Palumbo renovation (Pittsburgh Post Gazette)] *[http://www.goduquesne.com/facilities/duqu-facil-palumbo.html A.J. Palumbo Center] *[http://www.goduquesne.com Duquesne University Athletics] *[http://www.duq.edu Duquesne University] {{Duquesne Dukes men's basketball navbox}} {{Duquesne Dukes women's basketball navbox}} {{Atlantic 10 Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball navbox}} {{Pittsburgh}} {{coord|40.4374|-79.9879|region:US-PA_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Duquesne Dukes men's basketball]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Music venues in Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1988]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1988]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Music venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1988 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Continental Basketball Association venues]]

{{Infobox venue |nickname = Votanikos Arena |image = [[File:Paoathens3.jpg|260px]] |fullname = Votanikos Arena |location = [[Votanikos]], [[Athens]], [[Greece]] |coordinates = {{coord|37|59|10|N|23|41|27|E|type:landmark_source:kolossus-frwiki|display=inline}} |broke_ground = 2009 |renovated = |opening = |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Athens|Municipality of Athens]], [[Panathinaikos|Panathinaikos A.O.]] |operator = [[Panathinaikos|Panathinaikos A.O.]] |surface = |construction_cost = 80.000.000 € |architect = A&S ARCHITECTS |former_names = Votanikos Arena (Project name) |tenants = [[Panathinaikos F.C.]]
[[Panathinaikos A.O.]] |seating_capacity = 52,000 Football Stadium
8,000 Basketball Stadium
3,000 Volleyball Stadium |dimensions = | publictransit = {{OASA icons|M}} {{OASA icons|M3}} {{rint|athens|metro}} [[Eleonas metro station]] }} '''Panathinaikos New Stadium''' is a proposed football stadium with an additional multi-use sports complex in [[Athens]], [[Greece]], that will host all departments of the [[Panathinaikos]] sports club. The complex will be located in the historic [[Votanikos]] area, west of downtown Athens. The whole project includes the football stadium (seating 52,000), a basketball arena (8,000), a volleyball stadium (3,000), swimming pool, gymnastic facilities etc. The Votanikos area is a bit rubbish zone that has been in decline for several decades.{{lopsided|date=October 2018}} It currently houses mostly vacant, dilapidated storage and industrial facilities and has been in urgent need of redevelopment and improvements in infrastructure. The football stadium was to be ready for the 100 years of the club in 2008, with the rest of the complex completed by 2011. As of October 2013 and due to the club's and the country's financial troubles, the construction of the Votanikos Arena has stopped and consequently the plans for the demolition of the [[Apostolos Nikolaidis Stadium]] were cancelled. After another five-year spell at the Olympic Stadium, the team has returned to its traditional home ground once again. {{reflist}} {{Panathinaikos}} {{Panathinaikos FC}} [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums]] [[Category:Football venues in Greece]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Greece]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Greece]] [[Category:Sports venues in Athens]] [[Category:Proposed stadiums]] [[Category:Proposed buildings and structures in Greece]] {{Greece-sport-stub}} {{Athens-struct-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Olympic Stadium
Stade Olympique de Phnom Penh | nickname = | native_name = ពហុកីឡាដ្ឋានជាតិអូឡាំពិក | native_name_lang = kh | image = Olympic Stadium Phnom Penh tribuna 2012.jpg | caption = The Olympic Stadium in 2012 | logo_image = | logo_caption = | fullname = Olympic Stadium | former_names = | location = [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1963 | built = | opened = 1964 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = [[Vann Molyvann]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 50,000{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/04/04/construction-begins-on-chinese-funded-stadium-in-cambodia.html|title=Construction begins on Chinese-funded stadium in Cambodia|date=4 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=6 December 2017}} | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Cambodia national football team]]
[[Cambodian League]] }} The '''National Olympic Stadium''' ({{lang-km|ពហុកីឡាដ្ឋានជាតិអូឡាំពិក}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]]. It has a capacity of 50,000. Despite its name, the stadium has never hosted an [[Olympic Games]]. ==History== [[File:PP Olympic Stadium - Tennis courts.jpg|thumbnail|Tennis courts at the Olympic Stadium]] Construction on the National Sports Complex started in 1963 and was completed in 1964.[http://www.ka-tours.org/ Khmer Architecture Tours], retrieved 2007-11-25 Designer [[Vann Molyvann]] made use of massive [[Earthworks (engineering)|earthwork]]s to create the stadium, digging up 500,000 cubic meters of earth to shape the grounds.[http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/IJ27Ae02.html Deconstructing Cambodia's modernist heritage], Asia Times Online; retrieved 2007-11-25 The stadium might have been built to host the [[1963 Southeast Asian Peninsular Games]], but the games were cancelled due to political problems in Cambodia. There was also the short-lived [[GANEFO]] games, that were held in Phnom Penh, Cambodia in November 25~December 6, 1966 and were named 'First Asian GANEFO'. The stadium did play host to appearances by visiting dignitaries and state occasions, and was the home of Cambodia's national athletics teams. The stadium played a small part in the [[1966 FIFA World Cup]] when [[Korea DPR national football team|North Korea]] faced [[Australia national association football team|Australia]] in a qualifier as the two remaining Asia/Oceania zone teams.South Korea had been forced to withdraw due to logistical issues after the matches were moved from Japan, and South Africa, who had been moved to the zone, were disqualified after being suspended by FIFA due to apartheid. Because [[North Korea]] lacked diplomatic relations with most countries and did not have a suitable venue at the time, finding a suitable venue for the match proved difficult until Head of State [[Norodom Sihanouk]], an ally of [[Kim Il-sung]], said the matches could be held in Phnom Penh. The matches attracted 60,000 and 40,000 fans, with Sihounouk decreeing half would cheer for Australia, while the other half cheered the Koreans. The matches were held on 21 November 1965 and on 24 November 1965, with North Korea winning both (6–1 and 3–1). Because all African teams had withdrawn in protest against FIFA, North Korea automatically qualified for the final tournament, where they reached the quarter-finals.[http://www.gluckman.com/NKFootball.html The greatest story never told], Ron Gluckman; retrieved 2008-01-15[http://www.planetworldcup.com/CUPS/1966/wc66qualification.html 1966 Qualifying Competition], Planet World Cup; retrieved 2007-01-15 Among the facilities are [[Olympic size swimming pool|Olympic-size pools]] for swimming and diving and an indoor volleyball court with a capacity of up to 8,000, now known as the Olympic Stadium Indoor Arena. The diving boards and swimming pools were restored in 2017 after years of disuse, and are now enjoyed daily by the general public. During the [[Khmer Rouge]] era, the stadium was used as an execution site where officials of the [[Khmer Republic]] formerly led by [[Lon Nol]] were killed.[http://www.garella.com/rich/camnotes.htm Notes from Cambodia], Rich Garella; retrieved 2007-11-25 In the decades following the Khmer Rouge era, the stadium facilities fell into disrepair. In 2000, the stadium complex was redeveloped by a Taiwanese firm, the Yuanta Group, which refurbished the stadium but also redeveloped parcels of the complex into condominiums and commercial properties.[http://www.cambodiapolitic.org/disposals_of_state_properties.htm Illegal disposals of state property] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031201405/http://www.cambodiapolitic.org/disposals_of_state_properties.htm |date=2007-10-31 }}, CambodiaPolitic.org; retrieved 2007-11-25[http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/03/27/arts/cambarch.php Building Phnom Penh: An Angkorian heritage], Robert Turnbull, ''International Herald Tribune''; retrieved 2007-11-25 The stadium has come to be a popular attraction for Phnom Penh residents, who attend daily exercise sessions, as well as football games and other activities. In May 2007, the Irish singer [[Ronan Keating]] performed in concert in the stadium's Indoor Arena, the first concert by a major international act in Cambodia.[http://detailsaresketchy.wordpress.com/2007/05/05/ronan-keating-does-cambodia/ Ronan Keating does Cambodia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070520082004/http://detailsaresketchy.wordpress.com/2007/05/05/ronan-keating-does-cambodia/ |date=2007-05-20 }}, Details are Sketchy; retrieved 2007-11-25[http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2007/04/23/ronan_keating_to_perform_in_cambodia Ronan Keating to perform in Cambodia], Starpulse; retrieved 2007-11-25 In November–December 2007, the [[World Organization Volleyball for Disabled]] held its world cup in the stadium's Indoor Arena, the first major international sporting event in Cambodia in more than 40 years.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1678686,00.html Prosthetic Prowess], ''Time''; retrieved 2007-11-25[http://sports.inquirer.net/breakingnews/breakingnews/view_article.php?article_id=102873 Disabled world cup volleyball kicks off in Cambodia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005230601/http://sports.inquirer.net/breakingnews/breakingnews/view_article.php?article_id=102873 |date=2008-10-05 }}, Agence France Presse, via ''Inquirer''; retrieved 2007-11-25 Cambodia, seeded fourth in the world, finished third. In 2010, the stadium hosted all the football matches for the Cambodian Premier League, known for sponsorship purposes as the Metfone C-League. The [[2023 Southeast Asian Games]] will not be held at the Olympic Stadium, but at a new stadium under construction in another part of Phnom Penh, to be known as the [[Morodok Techo National Sports Complex]].{{cite web|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2012082458250/Sport/pp-sports-complex-plans-laid-bare.html |title=Phnom Penh sports complex plans laid bare |author=Yeun Ponlok and Ung Chamroeun |date=24 August 2012 |publisher=Phnom Penh post |accessdate=24 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826144301/http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2012082458250/Sport/pp-sports-complex-plans-laid-bare.html |archivedate=August 26, 2012 }} ==International Soccer Matches== {| class="wikitable" ! Date !! Competition!! Team !! Res !! Team !! Crowd |- | 11 Sep 2018 | International Friendly | {{fb|CAM}} | align=center |1-3 | {{fb|MAS}} | 50,000 |- | 8 Nov 2018 | [[2018 AFF Championship]] | {{fb|CAM}} | align=center |0-1 | {{fb|MAS}} | 34,250 |- | 20 Nov 2018 | [[2018 AFF Championship]] | {{fb|CAM}} | align=center |1-3 | {{fb|LAO}} | 25.000 (don't Sure) |} ==See also== *[[Sport in Cambodia]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|11|33|30.1|N|104|54|43.5|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Cambodia]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Cambodia]] [[Category:National stadiums|Cambodia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1963]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Phnom Penh]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Cambodia]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Phnom Penh]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ski area |name= Shymbulak Ski Resort |logo= |picture= |caption= |location= [[Kazakhstan]] |nearest_city= [[Almaty]] |coordinates={{coord|43|7|41|N|77|4|51|E|display=inline,title}} |top_elevation= {{convert|3200|m|ft|-2}} |base_elevation= {{convert|2200|m|ft|-2}} |vertical = {{convert|1000|m|ft|-2}} |skiable_area= |number_trails= |longest_run= |liftsystem= |terrainparks= |snowfall= |external_link=http://www.shymbulak.com/en/ |}}
'''Shymbulak''' ({{lang-kk|'''S'ymbulaq'''}}, ''Шымбұлақ''), also known as '''Chimbulak''' ({{lang-ru|Чимбулак}}) is a [[ski resort]] near [[Almaty]]. It is the largest ski resort in Central Asia. It is located in the upper part of the Medeu Valley in the [[Zaiilisky Alatau]] mountain range, at an elevation of {{convert|2200|m|ft|-2}} above sea level. The resort area is about {{convert|25|km|mi|0}} south of [[Almaty]] city by [[Medeo]] road. It is popular for its mild climate, large quantity of sunny days and great amount of snow through the winter (from November till May).<ref>[http://www.welovealmaty.com/shymbulak-ski-resort-almaty.html Symbulak Ski Resort]</ref>
==History==
Shymbulak (also known as "Chimbulak") was disscovered by amateur skiers in the 1940s. Soon after, it became the first downhill route in the Soviet Union. Skiers originally needed to climb up the mountain tops on foot (which took roughly 3 hours). In 1954 a 1500 meters ski tow was built. Starting from 1961, Shymbulak hosted several USSR Championships and the Silver Edelweisse prize skiing competitions. In 1983 it became the Olympic ski training center for the USSR. During this time, various commodities were built including restaurants and hotels.<ref>http://www.kazakhstandiscovery.com/history-of-shymbulak.html History of Shymbulak ]</ref>
The annual "Artyemenko" Prize competition has been held in Shymbulak since 2011. The competition is held on February. Almaty hosted the [[2011 Asian Winter Games]], bid for [[2014 Winter Olympics]], considered a bid for [[2018 Winter Olympics]], but decided to bid for [[2022 Winter Olympics]] instead; Shymbulak was a venue for the Alpine Skiing events (both speed and technical), and would have been for the latter.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/winter_olympic_bids/1216133778.html Almaty Considers 2018 Winter Games bid]</ref>
== Ski area information == [[Image:Shimbulak1.JPG|right|thumb|250px|Shymbulak Ski Area]] [[File:Shymbulak, Medeu District.jpg|thumb|Shymbulak in summer.]] The Shymbylak ski resort is located in the upper part of the Medeu Valley in the Zaiilisky Alatau mountain range, 25km from Almaty. The resort can be reach by Gondola cars from Meadeu.
The weather varies from {{convert|20|C|F}} in summer to {{convert|−7|C|F}} in winter and the snow base is about {{convert|1.5|to(-)|1.8|m|in|round=5}}.The average snowfall is around 1.5 m. The duration of the ski season is from November to April.
The ski areas span over 3000 ft of vertical drop (920m) and nearly 7.5 miles (12km) of ski runs. There are three ski lifts at the resort with the highest going to 3200 meters above sea level. There is also a Hotel located at the Resort, enabling those wishing to ski during the day, have a place to stay at night.
It is popular for its mild climate, large quantity of sunny days and great amount of snow through the winter (from November till May). The resort offers a ski and snowboard school. There is also ''Shymbulak'' hotel (4 stars) and [[ski]], [[snowboard]] and [[sleigh]] rentals.
There are three [[ski lift]]s, which cumulatively reach Talgar pass ({{convert|3200|m|ft|-2|disp=sqbr}} above the sea level), the highest point of the ski resort. The total length of the lifts is {{convert|3620|m|ft|-1}}. There are 3 stations of them; the first one is ''Intersection'' Station ({{convert|2260|m|ft|-1|disp=sqbr}} above the sea level) (9 minute trip), then ''20th Prop'' Station ({{convert|2630|m|ft|-1|disp=sqbr}} above the sea level) (16.5 minutes) and ''Talgar pass'' Station ({{convert|3200|m|ft|-2|disp=sqbr}} above the sea level). There is also ''Snow-Park'' for the fans of [[snowboarding]].

{{italic title}} '''''The Anfield Wrap''''' (TAW Player) is a collective of [[podcast]]s, radio shows, [[videocast]]s, live shows, magazine and website articles predominantly about [[Liverpool F.C.]] as well as the culture and music in the city of [[Liverpool]].
==Content== Described by sports journalist [[Barry Glendenning]] as "essential listening for Liverpool fans",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/mar/27/podcasts-football-weekly-barry-glendenning|title=They’re all talk but it seems everyone loves a podcast - Barry Glendenning|first=Barry|last=Glendenning|date=27 March 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> and averaging over 200,000 weekly downloads in over 200 countries including Vatican City<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.balls.ie/amp/football/the-anfield-wrap-370683|title=Meet One Of Liverpool's Biggest Success Stories - The Anfield Wrap|first=Gavin|last=Cooney|publisher=}}</ref> they have sold out venues in Australia, USA, Scandinavia as well as Ireland, Hong Kong, Dubai and England and a stage at the Sound City Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/liverpool/big-treat-for-irish-liverpool-fans-as-the-anfield-wrap-podcast-returns-to-dublin-for-a-live-show-35859590.html|title=Big treat for Irish Liverpool fans as The Anfield Wrap podcast returns to Dublin for a live show - Independent.ie|website=independent.ie|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.onlinejournalismblog.com/2016/03/11/this-uk-podcast-is-making-money-and-employs-4-people/|title=This UK podcast is making money – and employs 4 people|date=11 March 2016|website=onlinejournalismblog.com|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theanfieldwrap.com/2013/04/taw-down-under/|title=TAW DOWN UNDER - The Anfield Wrap|date=11 April 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theanfieldwrap.com/2013/06/taw_down-under_new_dates/|title=THE ANFIELD WRAP DOWN UNDER - NEW DATES ADDED - The Anfield Wrap|date=19 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/look-inside-new-york-pub-9886233|title=Look inside the New York pub dedicated to Liverpool legend Jamie Carragher|first=Dawn|last=Collinson|date=19 August 2015|website=liverpoolecho.co.uk|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jmu-journalism.org.uk/anfield-wrap-stage-set-for-sound-city/|title=Anfield Wrap stage set for Sound City|website=jmu-journalism.org.uk}}</ref>
As well as fan culture the shows have also contained interviews with [[Kevin Keegan]]<ref>https://www.theanfieldwrap.com/2018/10/taw-special-kevin-keegan-exclusive/</ref> [[Jürgen Klopp]], [[Kenny Dalglish]], [[Brendan Rodgers]], [[Rafa Benitez]], [[Gerard Houllier]], [[Rick Parry]], [[Jamie Carragher]], [[Lucas Leiva]] and [[Xabi Alonso]]. As of July 2017 the shows had received a total of 28,000,000 downloads worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sport360.com/article/football/english-premier-league/240151/the-anfield-wrap-from-humble-pubcasts-to-global-stars/|title=The Anfield Wrap: From humble pubcasts to global stars - Article - Sport360|website=www.sport360.com|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref>
''The Anfield Wrap'' have made and appeared on video clips for [[Sky Sports]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/watch/video/sports/football/9863051/gerrard-8211-the-anfield-wrap|title=Gerrard – The Anfield Wrap|website=skysports.com|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> and the Premier League World,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=E_OM15xMwAQ|title=The Anfield Wrap featured on Premier League World|first=|last=The Anfield Wrap|date=14 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=30 March 2018|via=YouTube}}</ref> and BBC’s Newsbeat<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/35552890/liverpool-ticket-price-rise-was-bad-pr-says-anfield-wrap-fanzine-editor|title=Liverpool ticket price rise was 'bad PR' says Anfield Wrap fanzine editor - BBC Newsbeat|first=Simon|last=Mundie|date=2 November 2016|website=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> as well as making an appearance on the [[Fox Sports]] documentary ''Being Liverpool'', and representing fan views on issues such as ticket prices and kick off times.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-fans-been-pushed-far-7335603|title=Why Liverpool still have a chance to right some wrongs over ticket scandal|first=Gareth|last=Roberts|date=9 February 2016|website=mirror.co.uk|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35546090|title=Liverpool owners scrap £77 ticket and apologise to fans|date=10 February 2016|publisher=|accessdate=30 March 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-30778377|title=Teatime Merseyside derby confirmed|date=30 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=30 March 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==Awards== ''The Anfield Wrap'' was awarded the Podcast Of The Year award in 2012 and 2015 by The [[Football Supporters Federation]] and Best Football Podcast at The Football Blogging Awards in 2016 and was The Football Supporters’ Federation Radio Show Of The Year 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theanfieldwrap.com/about/|title=About The Anfield Wrap - The Anfield Wrap|website=theanfieldwrap.com|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> They were nominated for club podcast of the year at the 2017 Football Supporters Federation Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsf.org.uk/latest-news/view/fsf-awards-2017-shortlists-announced|title=FSF Awards 2017 shortlists announced - Football Supporters' Federation|first=|last=http://www.fsf.org.uk/|website=www.fsf.org.uk}}</ref> At the 2018 British Podcast Awards The Anfield Wrap won silver, behind only [[Kermode and Mayo's Film Review]] in the listeners choice award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.radiotoday.co.uk/amp/2018/05/british-podcast-awards-2018-the-winners/|title=British Podcast Awards 2018 – the winners|publisher=}}</ref> On October 31st The Anfield Wrap was announced as nominated for the ‘Fan Media of the Year’ award at the 2018 Football Supporters Federation Awards.<ref>http://www.fsf.org.uk/latest-news/view/fsf-awards-2018-shortlists-announced</ref>

{{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Wielka Krokiew | nickname = | image = [[File:Wielka krokiew.jpg|300px]] | caption = | location = | city = [[Zakopane]] | country = {{flagicon|Poland}} [[Poland]] | opened = 1925 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | size = | k-spot = K-125 | hill size = HS 140 | hill record = {{flagicon|POL}} [[Kamil Stoch]]
(141.5m in 2018) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = [[1929 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]]
[[1939 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]]
[[1962 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] }} '''Wielka Krokiew''' (''The Great Krokiew'', in [[Polish language|Polish]] ''krokiew'' means ''rafter'') is the one - the biggest - of ski jumps built on the slope of Krokiew mountain (1378 m) in [[Zakopane]], [[Poland]]. It was opened in 1925. From 1989 the ski jump bears the official name '''Wielka Krokiew im. [[Stanislaw Marusarz|Stanisława Marusarza]]'''. It is a regular venue in the [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]]. The capacity of the ski jumping stadium is 40,000.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumzone.weebly.com/|title=StadiumZone|website=StadiumZone|accessdate=7 November 2018}} [[File:Wielka Krokiew 2014.jpg|thumb|right|300 px|Wielka Krokiew in 2014]] The hill was featured in competitions at the [[1939 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships|1939]] and [[1962 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] as well as the 2001 [[Universiade]]. In 1997, [[Pope]] [[John Paul II]], while visiting his native country, celebrated a [[mass (liturgy)|mass]] at the hill's stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/travels/documents/hf_jp-ii_hom_06061997_en.html|title=Zakopane - Beatifications|publisher=|accessdate=7 November 2018}} Since 2001, due to the success of Polish jumper [[Adam Małysz]], Wielka Krokiew has seen some of the largest audiences in [[FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup ski jumping]]. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commonscat-inline}} {{coord|49|16|46|N|19|57|55|E|region:PL_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=title}} [[Category:Sport in Zakopane]] [[Category:Ski jumping venues in Poland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lesser Poland Voivodeship]] {{Poland-sports-venue-stub}} {{skijumping-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Île Lacroix | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Patinoire de l'île Lacroix-1.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = Centre Sportif Guy Boissière
Avenue Jacques-Chastellain
76100 [[Rouen]], [[France]] | broke_ground = | built = | coordinates = {{coord|49|25|59|N|1|06|12|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} | opened = 14 Jan 1992 | renovated = 2010, refrigeration system updated | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = Artefact | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = [[Ice hockey|Hockey]]: 2747 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Dragons de Rouen]] | embedded = | website = }} '''Île Lacroix''' (English: ''Lacroix Island'') is an ice hockey arena in [[Rouen]], [[France]], named for the island it sits on. It is a part of the ''Centre Sportif Guy Boissière'' (English: ''Guy Boissière Sport Center''), formerly known as the ''Centre Sportif du Docteur Duchêne'' (English: ''Dr. Duchêne Sport Center''). It is the home arena of the [[Dragons de Rouen]] of the [[Ligue Magnus]]. The Île Lacroix features two [[ice rink]]s—an Olympic-sized rink with over 2700 spectator seats around it, and a smaller, public rink for recreational skating. The rinks were renovated in 2010, to change the ice-cooling systems over from [[Freon]] to [[R507]], in accordance with EU standards, at a cost of {{currency|2.35 million|EUR|first=yes}}.{{cite web|title=Réparation et préparation|url=http://www.rouenhockeyelite76.com/News306?PHPSESSID%3Da78cae76269ef85f72fba0e36275c6f8|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224061057/http://www.rouenhockeyelite76.com/News306?PHPSESSID%3Da78cae76269ef85f72fba0e36275c6f8 |dead-url=yes|archive-date=24 February 2011|accessdate=2 June 2012|language=fr}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ile Lacroix}} [[Category:Sports venues in Seine-Maritime]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in France]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in France]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1992]]
